thread.title: NZ dual nationals exempt from Trump's US Muslim travel ban
thread.title_full: NZ dual nationals exempt from Trump's US Muslim travel ban

author: Stacey Kirk
title: NZ dual nationals exempt from Trump's US Muslim travel ban
text:
NZ dual nationals exempt from Trump's US Muslim travel ban STACEY KIRK Last updated 11:02, February 1 2017 CAMERON BURNELL/FAIRFAX NZ. 
Bill English on USA Travel Ban 
New Zealanders who hold dual nationality with a country on US President Donald Trump's blacklist are not restricted to travel to the US if they hold a New Zealand passport and a US visa. 
The US Embassy in Wellington confirmed the exemption - previously reported as having been extended to other so-called "Five Eyes" countries - also applied to New Zealand. Together, New Zealand, Australia, Canada, Britain and the US make up the Five Eyes security network - the world's largest joint intelligence gathering operation. 
But there was a catch - the exemption won't apply to any dual New Zealand citizen who had visited one of the blacklisted countries in the last five years. 1 NEWS NOW 
White House spokesperson Sean Spicer says Donald Trump is "doing exactly what he told America would do". 
The Government had been scrambling for days to find out from the US whether dual New Zealand nationals were affected by Trump's Muslim ban. 
READ MORE: 
But the statement clarifying the US position on Wednesday appeared to have caught the Government on the hop, with Prime Minister Bill English seemingly unaware that it came with conditions. CARLOS BARRIA/REUTERS 
US President Donald Trump issued an executive order to impose tighter vetting of travellers entering the United States, sparking a worldwide rebuke. 
Speaking to reporters ahead of an all day caucus meeting, English said New Zealand officials had only been advised Wednesday morning that a statement was being issued. 
"I haven't seen the wording of the actual statement. What I've been advised is that dual citizens are not covered by the ban. So we don't see any reason why someone who is a New Zealander with dual citizenship would have any problems." 
Asked if he wished the policy had been handled better by the US, English responded: "I don't think this policy has been rolled out in a way that suited anybody much. So I would hope that if there are gong to be other significant changes in their policy they would implement it in ways that people understand it." HAGEN HOPKINS/GETTY IMAGES 
Prime Minister Bill English has been criticised for his response to President Trump's travel ban order. 
Trump signed an Executive Order at the weekend, temporarily suspending entry into the United States of foreign nationals from seven mostly-Muslim countries he claimed were terrorist havens. Ad Feedback 
They were Iraq, Syria, Sudan, Iran, Somalia, Libya, and Yemen. 
A spokeswoman for the US Embassy in New Zealand confirmed the ban did not apply to dual nationals who held a New Zealand passport, however those also from Iraq, Syria, Sudan and Iran still required a US visa. This was the case before the executive order. 
Dual nationals of Yemen, Libya, and Somalia and a Visa Waiver Programme country - such as New Zealand - may travel under the waiver programme unless they had travelled to any of the seven countries on or after March 2011. 
Any travel to those seven countries in the past five years would mean those New Zealand citizens would also have to apply for a US visa. 
The embassy was working closely with the Department of Homeland Security to implement Trump's executive order, the spokeswoman said. 
"Our embassies and consulates around the world will process visa applications and issue non-immigrant and immigrant visas to otherwise eligible visa applicants who apply with a passport from an unrestricted country, even if they hold dual nationality from one of the seven restricted countries. 
"We will announce any changes affecting travellers to the United States as soon as that information is available." 
US citizens (although they might also have another nationality) were required to use their US passport when entering and departing the United States. They did not receive visas or enter the US as a foreign national, so the Executive Order did not apply to them. 
New Zealand officials appeared to have been advised of the US position on New Zealand on Wednesday morning, after seeking answers for days. 
English was expected to speak to Trump by phone over coming days. Asked if he would raise the Muslim ban, English said he was "quite happy to represent the view" that New Zealand disagreed with the policy. 
He did not expect that to ruffle US feathers. 
"There's a long history of disagreement of New Zealanders with US policy, going right back to the Vietnam war in the 1950s. That doesn't change the need as a small country for a positive relationship with the US. We can do that at the same time as disagree with the US." - Stuff
